_meta.artifact_name: Coalition Coordination Strategy - Air Quality & Mold Risk Policy Scaling
_meta.policy_context: Scaling Air Quality & Mold Risk Policy Beyond Military Pilot
_meta.note: This is a STRATEGY document, not an execution plan. No external actions authorized without human approval.

strategic_objectives: Build effective coalition for policy scaling from military pilot to civilian application
Leverage coalition strengths (federal agencies, veterans orgs, health insurance) for maximum policy impact
Coordinate coalition efforts across multiple scaling pathways (veteran housing, public housing, schools, private residential)
Address coalition gaps systematically (evidence verification, opposition management, resource coordination)

strategic_approaches.rationale: Three-tier structure (core allies, strategic partners, grassroots partners) enables focused coordination while maintaining broad coalition support. Core steering committee provides leadership, working groups enable specialized coordination.
Specialized working groups enable focused coordination on evidence, economics, grassroots, and legislative strategy. Prevents coordination overload while maintaining strategic alignment.

working_groups.purpose: Evidence verification, peer review, health outcomes analysis
Cost-benefit analysis, economic case development, funding mechanisms
Grassroots narrative development, local advocacy, constituent engagement
Legislative vehicle identification, committee engagement, sponsor targeting

strategic_approaches.rationale: Engage Tier 1 core allies immediately for steering committee formation. Coordinate with EPA and HUD on rulemaking timelines. Build coalition structure before policy windows open.
engagement_sequence: Immediate: Veterans Organizations, EPA, HUD (steering committee formation)
Short-term: Health Insurance Industry, Public Health Organizations (economic case, evidence verification)
Medium-term: School Districts, Tenant Advocacy (grassroots mobilization)

strategic_approaches.rationale: Align coalition resources for maximum effectiveness. Federal agencies provide regulatory authority and technical expertise. Veterans orgs provide credibility and grassroots. Health insurance provides economic case and potential funding.

key_learnings: Coalition coordination is critical for policy scaling success
Tiered structure enables focused leadership while maintaining broad support
Early engagement of core allies establishes foundation
Evidence verification is prerequisite for coalition credibility

steering_committee.meeting_frequency: Monthly (or as needed for policy windows)
steering_committee.decision_authority: Strategic decisions require steering committee approval. Tactical decisions delegated to working groups.

working_group_coordination.coordination_structure: Working groups report to steering committee. Cross-group coordination through steering committee and designated liaisons.
working_group_coordination.information_sharing: Regular working group updates to steering committee. Shared information repository for coalition documents.
working_group_coordination.conflict_resolution: Steering committee resolves conflicts between working groups. Escalation path for unresolved issues.

external_coordination.policymaker_engagement: Steering committee coordinates high-level policymaker engagement (EPA, HUD, Congress). Working groups support with specialized expertise.
external_coordination.media_coordination: Health Insurance Industry and Veterans Organizations lead media coordination. Unified messaging framework across all coalition communications.
external_coordination.opposition_management: Steering committee develops opposition management strategy. Working groups provide specialized analysis (economic, legal, media).

tier_1_core_allies.engagement_approach: Immediate steering committee formation. High-touch coordination. Regular strategic meetings.
engagement_tactics: Shared decision-making on key strategy questions
success_indicators: Steering committee formed and meeting regularly

tier_2_strategic_partners.engagement_approach: Working group participation. Specialized contribution areas. Regular working group meetings.
engagement_tactics: Working group membership and active participation
Targeted policymaker engagement in area of expertise

tier_3_grassroots_partners.engagement_approach: Grassroots working group coordination. Narrative development. Local advocacy support.

primary_opponents.concerns: Cost burden of air quality monitoring and remediation requirements
coalition_response: Develop cost-sharing mechanisms (federal grants, insurance incentives)
Frame as voluntary standards with incentives where possible
Emphasize long-term cost savings (preventive vs. reactive)
Engage health insurance industry to provide economic case
Highlight tenant health benefits and reduced liability

primary_opponents.concerns: Construction costs and regulatory compliance burden
coalition_response: Emphasize preventive measures reduce long-term costs
Highlight insurance industry support for cost reduction
Frame as market differentiation opportunity (healthy buildings)
Provide technical assistance and best practices
Frame as federal coordination with state implementation flexibility
Emphasize state health department partnership role
Develop state implementation framework with flexibility
Highlight benefits of federal coordination (consistency, resources)
Engage state health departments as implementation partners

monitoring_mechanisms: Media monitoring (opposition statements, op-eds, social media)
response_protocol: Rapid response team (steering committee + working group leads)
Unified messaging framework for opposition responses
Coalition asset deployment (economic case, health evidence, tenant stories)
Strategic engagement (where appropriate) to address concerns

sources: Federal agency resources (EPA, HUD rulemaking budgets)
financial_resources.coordination_mechanism: Steering committee oversees resource allocation. Working groups propose resource needs. Transparent resource sharing agreements.

human_resources.staff_capacity: Federal agencies (EPA, HUD) provide staff capacity for regulatory coordination. Veterans organizations provide policy staff. Health insurance provides economic analysis staff.
human_resources.volunteer_capacity: Veterans organizations (800), Tenant advocacy (300), School districts/parents (600), Public health (200), Health insurance employees (600)
human_resources.expertise_availability: High - federal agencies (regulatory), public health (evidence), health insurance (economics), veterans orgs (policy)

technical_resources.evidence_synthesis: Public Health Organizations, Academic Research Institutions

activities: Steering committee formation (Veterans Organizations, EPA, HUD)
Working group establishment (Evidence, Economic, Grassroots, Legislative)
Evidence verification protocol (Evidence & Research working group)
Economic case development (Economic Analysis working group)
Narrative toolkit development (Grassroots Mobilization working group)
Legislative vehicle analysis (Legislative Strategy working group)
Sustain coalition coordination during rulemaking/legislative processes
Track policy progress and adjust tactics

coalition_structure_metrics: Steering committee formed and meeting regularly
All 4 working groups established and active
Coalition charter approved by all Tier 1 partners
policy_impact_metrics: EPA rulemaking incorporates coalition input (after evidence verification)
HUD public housing regulations reference coalition recommendations
State health department adoption of federal coordination framework

coalition_fragmentation.risk: Multiple pathways and working groups may create coordination challenges
coalition_fragmentation.mitigation: Strong steering committee leadership, clear working group mandates, regular coordination meetings, unified messaging framework

resource_constraints.risk: Insufficient resources for all coalition activities
resource_constraints.mitigation: Prioritize evidence verification and core activities. Phase lower-priority activities. Leverage coalition partner resources.

opposition_coalition.mitigation: Monitor opposition activity. Develop rapid response protocol. Leverage coalition assets (economic case, health evidence, credibility).

evidence_verification_delay.risk: Evidence verification may take longer than expected, delaying coalition activation
evidence_verification_delay.mitigation: Prioritize evidence verification. Develop verification protocol early. Engage academic/research partners for verification support.

recommendations: Form steering committee immediately (Veterans Organizations, EPA, HUD)
Establish all 4 working groups with clear mandates and deliverables
Develop coalition charter with decision-making authority and resource sharing agreements
Prioritize evidence verification (required before coalition activation)
Develop unified messaging framework for all coalition communications
Establish regular coordination mechanisms (steering committee monthly, working groups bi-weekly)
Create shared information repository for coalition documents
Develop opposition monitoring and rapid response protocol
Align coalition timeline with EPA and HUD rulemaking windows
Track coalition metrics to measure effectiveness and adapt strategy
Maintain coalition health through regular engagement and conflict resolution
Integrate coalition strategy with grassroots strategy for coordinated advocacy
